CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN.  (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

options.option_text: YES
NO

questions.question_text_1: What is the role of the Gaussian blur in the Canny edge detection algorithm, and how does the choice of the standard deviation parameter affect the performance of edge detection? Which option do you think best describes the role of the Gaussian blur and its relationship with the standard deviation parameter in the Canny edge detection algorithm?
question_texts: What is the role of the Gaussian blur in the Canny edge detection algorithm, and how does the choice of the standard deviation parameter affect the performance of edge detection? Which option do you think best describes the role of the Gaussian blur and its relationship with the standard deviation parameter in the Canny edge detection algorithm?

options.option_text: The Gaussian blur helps to reduce noise in the image and smooth out pixelintensity variations. The standard deviation parameter controls the amount of blurring applied,with higher values resulting in more aggressive smoothing, which may lead to loss of edge detail.

The Gaussian blur enhances edge contrast in the image and amplifies pixelintensity gradients. The standard deviation parameter determines the width of the blur kernel,with larger values resulting in sharper edges and finer details preserved.

The Gaussian blur serves to highlight high-frequency components in theimage and accentuate edge boundaries. The standard deviation parameter dictates the level ofdetail preserved, with smaller values preserving finer details but potentially amplifying noise.

The Gaussian blur functions to dilate edge regions in the image and expandthe edge boundaries. The standard deviation parameter controls the extent of dilation, withhigher values resulting in broader edge regions but also increasing the risk of false edgedetections.

questions.question_text_1: Which property of the SIFT descriptor is primarily responsible for its resilience to changes in scale, viewpoint, and illumination?
question_texts: Which property of the SIFT descriptor is primarily responsible for its resilience to changes in scale, viewpoint, and illumination?

options.option_text: Scale space representation
Histogram of gradients
Keypoint detection
Orientation assignment

questions.question_text_1: In the Maximally Stable External Regions (MSER) algorithm, how does the tree structure contribute to the efficiency of region stability analysis?
question_texts: In the Maximally Stable External Regions (MSER) algorithm, how does the tree structure contribute to the efficiency of region stability analysis?

options.option_text: By enabling quick access to all regions in constant time.
By allowing for parallel computation of stability measures across regions.
By organizing regions hierarchically based on stability, facilitating efficientstability analysis.
By providing a compact representation of pixel intensities within each region,reducing computational overhead.

questions.question_text_1: In which scenarios is the Random Sample Consensus (RANSAC) algorithm more suitable compared to least squares?
question_texts: In which scenarios is the Random Sample Consensus (RANSAC) algorithm more suitable compared to least squares?

options.option_text: When the dataset contains a high percentage of outliers or erroneous datapoints.
When the dataset consists of noise-free and well-behaved data with minimaloutliers.
When the computational resources are limited, and quick solutions arerequired.
When the dataset is small, and exact solutions are necessary withoutconsidering outliers.

questions.question_text_1: In what way does VLAD (Vector of Locally Aggregated Descriptors) differ from Bag of Words (BoW) in representing visual features in images?
question_texts: In what way does VLAD (Vector of Locally Aggregated Descriptors) differ from Bag of Words (BoW) in representing visual features in images?

options.option_text: VLAD captures spatial relationships between local descriptors, while BoW doesnot.
BoW captures spatial relationships between local descriptors, while VLAD doesnot.
VLAD and BoW both capture spatial relationships between local descriptors.
Neither VLAD nor BoW capture spatial relationships between local descriptors.

questions.question_text_1: How does pyramid matching differ from Speeded-Up Robust Features (SURF) in image matching?
question_texts: How does pyramid matching differ from Speeded-Up Robust Features (SURF) in image matching?

options.option_text: Pyramid matching matches images at multiple resolutions using multi-resolution representations, while SURF focuses on detecting and describing local featuresinvariant to scale and rotation.
SURF relies on gradient-based descriptors for feature matching, whereaspyramid matching utilizes histogram-based representations.
Pyramid matching is computationally more efficient compared to SURF, whichrequires extensive feature extraction and matching procedures.

SURF is more suitable for matching images with complex patterns andcluttered backgrounds, while pyramid matching excels in scenarios where multi-scale matching iscritical, such as image registration across different resolutions.

questions.question_text_1: In the context of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), what is the primary challenge associated with backpropagation compared to traditional feedforward neural networks?
question_texts: In the context of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), what is the primary challenge associated with backpropagation compared to traditional feedforward neural networks?

options.option_text: The increased number of parameters and layers in CNNs makebackpropagation computationally intensive and prone to overfitting.
The presence of convolutional and pooling layers in CNNs requires thedevelopment of specialized backpropagation algorithms for efficient gradient computation.
The non-linear activation functions used in CNNs introduce discontinuities inthe error surface, making it difficult to find the global minimum during backpropagation.
The spatial structure of CNNs results in weight sharing and local connectivity,requiring careful consideration of the error propagation process during backpropagation.

questions.question_text_1: What is the primary advantage of Depthwise Separable Convolutions compared to standard Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) convolutions?
question_texts: What is the primary advantage of Depthwise Separable Convolutions compared to standard Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) convolutions?

options.option_text: Depthwise Separable Convolutions reduce computational complexity andmemory footprint by separating the spatial and channel-wise convolutions.
Depthwise Separable Convolutions introduce additional parameters to capturecomplex spatial relationships within feature maps.
Depthwise Separable Convolutions increase model capacity by performingconvolutions across multiple layers of the network.
Depthwise Separable Convolutions enhance feature representation byincorporating multiscale convolutions within the same layer.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following strategies can help mitigate the risk of overfitting when fine-tuning pretrained models on a small dataset?
question_texts: Which of the following strategies can help mitigate the risk of overfitting when fine-tuning pretrained models on a small dataset?

options.option_text: Increasing the depth and width of the neural network architecture to capturemore complex patterns in the data.
Applying dropout regularization to randomly deactivate neurons duringtraining to prevent co-adaptation of features.
Decreasing the learning rate during fine-tuning to ensure more stableconvergence and smoother optimization.
Increasing the batch size during fine-tuning to improve the stability of gradientestimation and accelerate convergence.

questions.question_text_1: What is the primary advantage of visualizing patches of maximally activating neurons in neural network interpretation?
question_texts: What is the primary advantage of visualizing patches of maximally activating neurons in neural network interpretation?

options.option_text: It helps identify the specific input features that contribute most strongly to themodel’s predictions.
It provides insights into the architectural design choices made in the neuralnetwork.
It quantifies the uncertainty associated with the model’s predictions.
It measures the computational resources required to activate the neurons.

questions.question_text_1: Which layer of the neural network does Grad-CAM typically operate on?
question_texts: Which layer of the neural network does Grad-CAM typically operate on?

options.option_text: The input layer.
The output layer.
The convolutional layers.
The fully connected layers.

questions.question_text_1: Which component of Grad-CAM is responsible for weighting the importance of each feature map?
question_texts: Which component of Grad-CAM is responsible for weighting the importance of each feature map?

options.option_text: The class activation map (CAM).
The global average pooling layer.
The guided backpropagation algorithm.
The gradient of the target class score with respect to the feature maps.

questions.question_text_1: What is the primary role of the Gram matrix in neural style transfer?
question_texts: What is the primary role of the Gram matrix in neural style transfer?

options.option_text: To compute the style loss by measuring the similarity between feature mapsfrom the content and style images.
To generate high-resolution images by applying a series of convolutions andupsampling operations.
To regularize the optimization process by penalizing large gradients in thefeature space.
To visualize the internal representations learned by the neural network duringtraining.

questions.question_text_1: What is a potential limitation of non-maximum suppression (NMS) algorithms in object detection?
question_texts: What is a potential limitation of non-maximum suppression (NMS) algorithms in object detection?

options.option_text: They are computationally expensive and can significantly increase inferencetime.
They may fail to suppress redundant bounding boxes in cluttered scenes withmultiple overlapping objects.
They require extensive hyperparameter tuning to achieve optimalperformance across different datasets.
They are highly sensitive to variations in lighting conditions and viewpoints inthe input images.

questions.question_text_1: What is a key feature of focal loss that distinguishes it from traditional loss functions in object detection?
question_texts: What is a key feature of focal loss that distinguishes it from traditional loss functions in object detection?

options.option_text: Focal loss introduces additional regularization terms to penalize large weightsin the neural network.
Focal loss dynamically adjusts the loss weights based on the difficulty of eachtraining example.
Focal loss computes the loss based on the Euclidean distance betweenpredicted and groundtruth bounding boxes.
Focal loss prioritizes minimizing the overall loss across all classes equally.

questions.question_text_1: What is a unique challenge faced by Siamese networks in comparison to traditional neural networks?
question_texts: What is a unique challenge faced by Siamese networks in comparison to traditional neural networks?

options.option_text: Siamese networks require significantly larger datasets for training due to theircomplex architecture.
Siamese networks need to learn a similarity metric between pairs of inputsamples, which requires specialized loss functions and training procedures.
Siamese networks are computationally more intensive, making them lessscalable for real-time applications.
Siamese networks tend to suffer from overfitting more frequently thantraditional neural networks due to their increased model complexity.

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following assertion and reason, and state which of them is true.  Assertion: ProgressiveGAN uses Minibatch Standard Deviation.  Reason: This value will be different if the generated images do not have the same diversity as the actual images, and the discriminator will penalize it as a result.
question_texts: Consider the following assertion and reason, and state which of them is true.  Assertion: ProgressiveGAN uses Minibatch Standard Deviation.  Reason: This value will be different if the generated images do not have the same diversity as the actual images, and the discriminator will penalize it as a result.

options.option_text: Both Assertion and Reason are True; Reason is a correct explanation of theAssertion
Both Assertion and Reason are True; but Reason is not a correct explanation ofthe Assertion
Assertion is True; Reason is False
Assertion is False by itself

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is false?
question_texts: Which of the following statements is false?

options.option_text: Reparametrization trick is used in training VAEs to overcome the problem ofnon-differentiability of the objective function across a sampling step.
In denoising autoencoder, reconstructed output is compared against noise-free ground truth data point.
While training a GAN, Generator and Discriminator weights are not updatedconcurrently but updated sequentially.
When a GAN is completely trained, Discriminator D outputs very highprobability (approximately 1) for images from Generator G, that is, D(G(z)) ≈ 1
Continual learning
Zero-shot learning
Few-shot learning
Unsupervised learning

questions.question_text_1: What is the advantage of the progressive training methodology proposed in the Progressive GAN paper?
question_texts: What is the advantage of the progressive training methodology proposed in the Progressive GAN paper?

options.option_text: It allows for generating high-resolution images with unlimited variation.
It eliminates the need for using mini-batches during training.
It enables the discovery of large-scale structures before finer-scale details.
It ensures all layers in the networks remain fixed throughout the trainingprocess.

questions.question_text_1: Contrastive Language Image Pre-training (CLIP) Can be used as a zero-shot classifier.
question_texts: Contrastive Language Image Pre-training (CLIP) Can be used as a zero-shot classifier.

options.option_text: TRUE
FALSE
Maximum likelihood estimate
Minimum likelihood estimate
Maximizing mean square error
Minimizing mean square error
Maximizing negative log likelihood
Minimizing negative log likelihood

question_texts: NOTE: Enter your answer in two decimal places.

questions.question_text_1: Consider a Faster R-CNN object detection framework, which is being trained with a mini-batch size of 2. The RPN produces 512 proposals, out of which 10 and 12 of them are foreground proposals, corresponding to each image in the mini-batch. For a single mini-batch update, the bounding box regression loss will be computed _____________ times.
question_texts: Consider a Faster R-CNN object detection framework, which is being trained with a mini-batch size of 2. The RPN produces 512 proposals, out of which 10 and 12 of them are foreground proposals, corresponding to each image in the mini-batch. For a single mini-batch update, the bounding box regression loss will be computed _____________ times.
